page.title: Sample 2: Using a Flowchart to Collect Data
page.contents:
This data collection technique uses a flowchart to organize the information collected.

Learners mingle to collect information about others, asking, for example, the following questions:

  • What jobs do the women and men in your family have?
  • What are the home activities of men and women in your family?

As before, students work in small groups to discuss their findings. Useful sentence frames could be as follows:

  • Many more men than women _________.
  • A common job for women in our class is _____________.

page.title: Using the Class Data With a Paragraph Frame
page.contents:
Now learners can use their data and ideas from their discussion to write using a paragraph frame.

Paragraph Frame for Scaffolding and Comparing

_______ and _______ differ in some ways, too. First, women _______, whereas _______ _______. In addition, _______ _______ _______ . In contrast, _______ . These differences help us to see _______ .

page.title: Overview: Developing an Academic Register
page.contents:
Â 

Informal Spoken Language

Academic Spoken Language

More Tier 1, everyday vocabulary appears; repetition of words.

A variety of words is used; more sophisticated.

Simple conjunctions and sentences may start with âandâ or âbut.â

Sentences start with transition words, such as âhowever,â âmoreover,â and âin addition.â

Slang and colloquial language such as âwhateverâ and âlikeâ may be used.

Replaces slang with accurate descriptions (As an exampleâ¦).

Speech reductions such as âwannaâ and âgonnaâ are used.

Speech tends to be more deliberate and words fully articulated.

Can vary greatly by ethnicity, region, gender, and age.

This common language register is used by people of a variety of backgrounds.

Listen to audio:

audio

Audio transcript


Now letâs turn to spoken academic language. At the beginning of this unit, we compared the text message between spouses and a conversation with a boss. An information register is completely appropriate in casual, social settings. However, to be heard and taken seriously in academic and professional settings, ELLs need to acquire an academic spoken register.

  • Teach academic language frames.

Please see Unit 4 in this module for an extensive overview of the academic language that accompanies critical thinking.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0170.mp3

Audio transcript


As language teachers, we can support the development of an academic register by adult ELLs through explicit instruction of the language needed to, for example. elaborate or clarify, build on, or challenge a partnerâs ideas. We also can provide scaffolds for preparing for academic and professional conversations. At the Academic Language and Literacy website, Jeff Zwiers recommends ways to move students beyond simply reporting ideas in an activity to building on their ideas, or, as he says, fortifying those ideas. Kate Kinsella (2012) offers ideas for preparing learners for academic discussions. This section of Unit 1 includes a brief introduction to building academic and professional conversations. Because these academic conversations are so closely aligned to expressing critical thinking, Unit 4 in this module will provide a much more extensive overview of this topic. Letâs look at a few tools and tasks appropriate for helping adults develop an academic and professional spoken register. Before continuing, letâs meet Inez from Ecuador.

page.title: Meet Inez From Ecuador
page.contents:
In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Inez's needs (analysis of Inez's needs) and identified the following personal and professional goals:

Personal goals:

  • Build her confidence when speaking in English.
  • Support her children's academic achievement.
  • Share literacy experiences with her children.
  • Read documents sent home from her children's school.
  • Take part in community activities and events that affect the well-being of her family.

Professional goals:

  • Immediate: Improve her ability to communicate with others at work (coworkers and supervisors).
  • Move out of a low-wage job in housekeeping.
  • Long-term: Become a nurse.

TASK: Review the analysis of Inez's needs and identify those related specifically to the development professional oral communication.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0180.mp3

Audio transcript


Inez has three school-aged children. She works in housekeeping at a hotel and is enrolled in a low-intermediate-level English class at a volunteer-run program in her community. The program she attends has a largely life-skills curriculum. Inez feels frustrated because people do not understand her. She has a hard time explaining problems because she cannot express herself well in English. She has trouble communicating with her boss. Her dream is to earn a high school equivalency diploma and then to become a nurse.

Inez has several needs related to acquiring more academic language. For this task, look specifically at the personal and professional goals where she would benefit from practice with a more professional oral language.

page.title: Teach the Language Needed to Engage in Academic Conversations
page.contents:
Elaborate and Clarify

How so?
What do you mean by...?
What makes you think that?
Why is that important

Synthesize Conversations

We can say that...
We all agree that...

Paraphrase Ideas

It sounds like...
In other words...

Build on a Partner's Idea

I would add that...
I want to add to your idea...

Challenge a Partner's Idea

Well, I think that...
Another way to look at it is...

Support Ideas with Examples

An example from my life is...
For example...

In their book, Academic Conversations, Zwiers and Crawford (2011) identify the core communication skills needed to engage in and sustain academic conversations, including the following:

  • Elaborate and clarify ideas.
  • Support ideas with examples.
  • Paraphrase ideas.
  • Build on and challenge a partner's opinion.
  • Synthesize conversations.

Adult ELLs need the phrases for these language functions made explicit (Finn Miller, 2014):

  • Model the language needed.
  • Provide sentence frames.
  • Post the phrases on the board.
  • Provide academic conversation starters.

page.title: Provide Scaffolds for Discussions
page.contents:
Kinsella (2012) provided a template for discussion for Kâ12 classrooms and recommended the following steps: Think, Write, Discuss, Record. That template has been simplified here as a linear string graphic organizer.

  • Adult ELLs can do the following:
  • Use a simple graphic organizer to plan for a discussion.
  • Discuss their ideas using notes from the brainstorm.
  • Use the graphic organizer to record notes while listening to peers.
  • Synthesize what they've heard and report to the class.

This can be combined with academic conversation sentence frames.

page.title: Developing a Professional Discourse
page.contents:
A formal register for adult ELLs has the following benefits:

  • Allows students to engage positively and actively with individuals in both one-on-one and team settings.
  • Gives tools for seeking and offering clarification (clarifying questions, paraphrasing, restating) appropriately.
  • Builds learner confidence.
  • Helps adult ELLs participate in professional conversations, make contributions, and encourage the contributions of others

Liz Andress at the Ronald M. Hubbs Center for Lifelong Learning creates posters with learners to highlight those differences.

Formal/Informal Language for Common Interactions in the Classroom and at Work by Elizabeth Andress, October 2014, presented as part of an Adult Intermediate ELL Unit on Communication. American Institutes for Research reprinted with permission from the author.

page.title: Developing the Academic Vocabulary of Adult ELLs
page.contents:
Tier 3

Content specific; often in textbooks and work documents (e.g., stethoscope, numerator)

Tier 2

General academic vocabulary used across disciplines and workplace settings (e.g., compare, analyze, evaluate)

Tier 1

Words and phrases of everyday speech; often concrete and used in spoken language (e.g., family, book, animal)

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0190.mp3

Audio transcript


Now letâs turn to the development of an academic and professional vocabulary. Three tiers of vocabulary can be used to teach adult ELLs: Tier 1 words are very common, concrete words used in everyday contexts, especially in speech, for example, family, book, funny, and good. Tier 2 words are general academic words used across disciplines and workplace settings, for example, concept, device, compare, and analyze. Then there are the very specialized, content-specific words adult ELLs may encounter in academic and work settings, such as stethoscope in a nursing assistant class or numerator in a mathematics class. These words often can be taught in context with visuals or realia, through models and demonstrations. We will concentrate on Tier 2 in this section because they help learners in a variety of contextsâpersonal, educational, and professional. First, we examine what it means to know a word well.

page.title: What Does It Mean to âKnowâ a Word?
page.contents:
accurate /ËÃ¦kyÉrÉt/ adjective

Definition: Free from mistakes or errors

(From the Merriam Webster LearnerDictionary)

Is this all we need to know?

Aside from the definition, the pronunciation, and the part of speech of the word accurate, we need to know the following:

  • Its spelling: a-c-c-u-r-a-t-e
  • Its register: primarily used in relatively formal writing and speaking for academic or professional purposes
  • Its frequency: Is it on AWL?
  • Its grammar: It modifies and precedes a noun: The supervisor expects an accurate report from the team by Tuesday.
  • Its collocations: It is regularly used to describe information, data, measurements, and reports.
  • Its connotations: Accurate has a positive connotation; inaccurate has a negative connotation.
  • Its derivations or word family members: accurate, inaccurate, accuracy, inaccuracy, accurately, inaccurately

(Dutro & Kinsella; 2010; Nation, 1990; Scarcella, 2003)

page.title: Using the Academic Word List
page.contents:
TASK: Download AWL sublist 1. Which words could be included in lessons you currently teach?

The Academic Word List (AWL) is a list of words that appear with high frequency in English-language academic texts. The list was compiled by Averil Coxhead at the Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand, and contains 570 word families, divided into 10 sublists. Sublist 1 consists of the 60 most common words. Sublist 2 contains the next most frequently used words and so on. The words selected occur frequently across a range of academic subjects. This means that it is useful to students who wish to study in any file. In addition, these words include vocabulary of everyday usage, equally useful to those who do not have academic goals.

This vocabulary is essential for adult ELLs seeking further education and training. It also is useful for those not yet entering into further formal studies. Many of these words are frequently heard on television, radio, and movies or in everyday conversation, and they may be found in newspapers, magazines, and novels. The following examples demonstrate that we are talking about words that cross subject areas and that are not specialized: create, theory, function, issue, environment, vary, available, and benefit.

Research (Nation, 2001) indicates that knowing the AWL significantly improves learnersâ understanding of academic texts. For details on the development and evaluation of the AWL, see Coxhead (2000).

page.title: The Academic Word List Highlighter
page.contents:
The online AWL highlighter identifies core academic vocabulary in a text.

An instructor (or a learner) can type or paste a text into a box, select a sublist level, and click submit. The text will be returned with AWL words, at the levels selected, highlighted in bold type. See what happens with the first paragraph of the personality and birth-order theory reading for sublists 1 and 2.

page.title: The Academic Word List Highlighter
page.contents:
Birth-order theory is a sociological and psychological concept that describes the tendency for people born into a particular birth order in a family (oldest, youngest, middle, or only child) to have certain personality traits. It is believed that because parents treat children in each birth order differently, children develop distinctively different personalities. It is found that children from within each group often share some common characteristics.

Try this with a text from your curriculum!

page.title: Steps for Presenting New Vocabulary
page.contents:
Dutro and Kinsella (2010) proposed the following steps for presenting new vocabulary to ELLs:

  • Write the word and pronounce it a few times.
  • Break long words into syllables and tap or clap out syllables, emphasizing the stressed syllable.
  • Lead students in quick pronunciation practice.
  • Explain the word clearly using student-friendly language (this is where learner dictionaries can be helpful).
  • Provide a visual representation or have learners create a picture, if feasible.
  • Give two easy to understand examples.
  • Engage learners in structured oral and written tasks.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT2_0200.mp3

Audio transcript


What are the most effective ways to teach vocabulary? First, whatever vocabulary you teach should be derived from the reading or content you are working on. In other words, do not teach random sets of words. Dutro and Kinsella (2010) highlighted the importance of a multistep approach that includes saying the word, using learner-friendly explanations and examples, presenting the word visually, and engaging the learners in structured oral and written practice with the words. Now you will see a few examples of what that can look like with adult ELLs.

When you teach new vocabulary, do you make sure your learners can pronounce the words correctly? Being understood by others is as important as knowing how and when to use words or phrases. Research indicates that learners who are unintelligible in their speech may face discrimination (Derwing & Munroe, 2005).

In the same lesson, George has learners practice recognizing and producing the correct word stress patterns for the personality trait vocabulary. Learners start by matching words to the correct word-stress pattern. The large circle represents the stressed syllable.

page.title: The Frayer Model for Working on Academic Vocabulary
page.contents:
The Frayer Model is a strategy that uses a graphic organizer for vocabulary building. Adult ELLs perform the following tasks:

  • Define the target vocabulary words or concepts.
  • Generate examples and non-examples.

This information is placed on a chart to provide a visual representation for learners. The benefits are as follows:

  • Can be used with the entire class, small groups, or for individual work
  • Draws on a student's prior knowledge to build connections among new concepts
  • Compares attributes and examples
  • Creates a visual reference

Consult the following for further reading: Frayer Model (n.d.).

Source: Frayer, D., Frederick, W. C., and Klausmeier, H. J. (1969). A Schema for Testing the Level of Cognitive Mastery: Working Paper no. 16. Madison, WI: Wisconsin Research and Development Center for Cognitive Learning. http://brainimaging.waisman.wisc.edu/~perlman/frayer-frederick-klausmeier.pdf. Used with permission from the Wisconsin Center for Education Research.

page.title: Applying the Principles in Your Setting
page.contents:
Let's review the strategies for teaching in a way that addresses academic language at all levels:

  • Use real-world data.

  • Use graphic organizers to show text structure.
  • Use the AWL and its tools.
  • Identify the academic vocabulary (especially Tier 2).
  • Teach all aspects of a word.
